solution.tex: Let $f(z)=\frac{1}{z^4+1}$. Then $f$ is an even function and the integral we want is \[\frac{1}{2}\int_\mathbb{R}f(z)dz.\] The denominator of $f$ is $z^4-1$ which has roots where $z^4=-1=e^{\pi i}$. The four solutions to this are $z=e^{i\theta}$ for $\theta=\frac{\pi}{4},\frac{3\pi}{4},\frac{5\pi}{4},\frac{7\pi}{4}$. Let $\alpha=e^{i\frac{\pi}{4}}$. Then $z^4-1=(z-\alpha)(z-i\alpha)(z+\alpha)(z+i\alpha)$. Let $c(t)=Re^{it}$ for $R>1$ and $t\in[0,\pi]$ and let $p(t)=t$ for $t\in[-R,R]$. Let $\gamma$ be the concatenation of the two. Then Cauchy's integral formula applied to $\gamma$ and $f$ gives \[\int_\gamma f(z)dz=\int_\gamma\frac{1}{(z-\alpha)(z-i\alpha)(z+\alpha)(z+i\alpha)}dz=\int_\gamma\frac{\frac{1}{(z-i\alpha)(z+\alpha)(z+i\alpha)}}{z-\alpha}dz+\int_\gamma\frac{\frac{1}{(z-\alpha)(z+\alpha)(z+i\alpha)}}{z-i\alpha}dz\] \[=2\pi i\left(\frac{1}{(\alpha-i\alpha)(\alpha+\alpha)(\alpha+i\alpha)}+\frac{1}{(i\alpha-\alpha)(i\alpha+\alpha)(i\alpha+i\alpha)}\right)\] \[=2\pi i\left(\frac{1}{4\alpha^3}+\frac{1}{-4i\alpha^3}\right)=\frac{\pi}{2}(i-1)\alpha^{-3}=\frac{\pi}{2}\sqrt{2}e^{\frac{3\pi}{4}i}e^{-\frac{3\pi}{4}i}=\frac{\pi}{\sqrt 2}.\] Estimating the integral over $c$ as $R\to\infty$ gives \[\left|\int_cf(z)dz\right|\leq\int_c|f(z)||dz|=\int_c\left|\frac{1}{z^4+1}\right||dz|\leq\int_0^\pi\frac{1}{R^4-1}dt=\frac{R\pi}{R^4-1}\to0.\] As $R\to\infty, p\to\mathbb{R}$ so our desired integral is \[\frac{1}{2}\int_\mathbb{R}f(z)dz=\frac{\pi}{2\sqrt 2}.\]
